medium: Stereo daguerreotype with hand-colored additions and punched indentations
creditline: Museum purchase, gift of the Florence Gould Foundation
inscribed: Printed label affixed verso lower right corner:  SAMMLUNG / Alf. Gouin (inscribed in pencil in unknown hand) / 1.132 / UWE SCHEID

makers.displaymaker: Alexis Louis Charles Arthur Gouin, French, 1799/1800–1855

texts.textentryhtml: The image that you see in the stereoscope is a simulation of binocular vision. By using the device to look at the two photographs taken from slightly different angles, the pictures converge into a single three-dimensional image. In the later part of the nineteenth century, stereoscopic photographs were a sensation; not only were they used as a tool to further the study of vision but they also became a form of affordable entertainment. This colored stereoscopic view captures the sitter’s amusement while imagining herself as royalty.

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1998," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 58, no. 1/2 (1999): p. 86-123.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Art Museum 1998," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 58, no. 1/2 (1999): p. 86-123., p. 100 (illus.), p. 103
